title: Stacking packaging for power modules
content: A multi-domain passive module with functionality embedded in the substrate has been developed by Saras Micro Devices. The Saras Tile, or STILE, enables power regulation from system board to package. ... The post Stacking packaging for power modules appeared first on Electronics Weekly.

uplifting_analysis.reasoning: Saras Micro Devices developed a new power module, STILE, that enables power regulation from system board to package. This innovation could lead to more efficient power usage in electronic devices, potentially reducing energy consumption and improving device performance. The multi-domain passive module with functionality embedded in the substrate suggests a novel approach to power management.

title: Most Financial Services Firms In Singapore Struggle To Align Their Brand Promise To CX
content: The results from Forrester’s 2025 study on total experience — covering major banks, investment firms, and health insurers — are in. title: OpenAI Targets Banking, Warner Bros. Considers Sales Options | Bloomberg Tech 10/21/2025
content: Bloomberg’s Ed Ludlow discusses OpenAI’s secretive project to train its artificial intelligence to build financial models and what that could mean for junior bankers. Plus, President Donald Trump announced a deal with Australia on rare earths to counter China's dominance. And shares of Warner Bros. Discovery jumped after the company said it has expanded a strategic review of the business to maximize shareholder value. (Source: Bloomberg)

uplifting_analysis.reasoning: OpenAI's project to train AI for financial models could lead to more efficient financial systems. The deal between President Trump and Australia on rare earths aims to counter China's dominance, potentially diversifying supply chains and reducing reliance on a single source. Warner Bros. Discovery's strategic review aims to maximize shareholder value, which could lead to restructuring or new initiatives.

title: Energy Independence with Home Batteries
content: There is no denying that the Australian federal government’s Cheaper Home Battery program has been a resounding success. title: Specification Pattern: DDD Beyound aggregates, entities and value
content: The Specification pattern tests whether objects meet specific requirements. In traditional approaches, business rules are often scattered throughout entities, services, or repositories, making them difficult to test, reuse, and modify. The Specification pattern centralizes these rules into dedicated classes. submitted by /u/73mp74710n [link] [comments]

uplifting_analysis.reasoning: The Specification pattern promotes better organization and maintainability of business rules, leading to more robust and reliable software systems. This centralization makes the rules easier to test, reuse, and modify, ultimately benefiting the users of the software by providing a more stable and adaptable product. The pattern encourages collaboration by providing a clear and consistent way to define and implement business logic.

title: [R] We figured out how to predict 32B model reasoning performance with a 1B model. 100x cheaper. Paper inside.
content: Remember our 70B intermediate checkpoints release? We said we wanted to enable real research on training dynamics. Well, here's exactly the kind of work we hoped would happen. rBridge: Use 1B models to predict whether your 32B model will be good at reasoning. Actually works. The problem: Small models can't do reasoning (emergence happens at 7B+), so how do you know if your training recipe works without spending $200k? Our solution: Align evaluation with both pre-training objective AND target task Use frontier model reasoning traces as gold labels Weight tokens by task importance automatically Results: 100x compute reduction vs baselines Accurately predict which datasets are worth training on R¬≤ = 0.826 predicting 32B performance from 1B proxy Works zero-shot on new datasets Tested on: GSM8K, MATH500, ARC-C, MMLU Pro, CQA, HumanEval Paper: https://www.arxiv.org/abs/2509.21013 This is what open research looks like - building on each other's work to make LLM development accessible to everyone, not just companies with infinite compute. Code coming soon. Apache 2.0 as always. submitted by /u/jshin49 [link] [comments]

uplifting_analysis.reasoning: Researchers are developing a method to predict the reasoning performance of large language models using smaller, more accessible models. This allows for more efficient and cost-effective development of AI, making it accessible to a wider range of researchers and developers, and fostering open research and collaboration.

title: Your Remote Team Could Be Putting Your Company Data at Risk. Take These Steps to Protect It.
content: As remote work becomes permanent for many companies, organizations must implement cost-effective data security measures to protect sensitive company information.

uplifting_analysis.reasoning: The article discusses implementing data security measures to protect sensitive company information as remote work becomes permanent. This suggests an attempt to adapt to new challenges and maintain operational integrity, benefiting a broad group of employees and stakeholders by safeguarding their data and the company's stability. The focus on cost-effective measures implies an attempt to make these solutions accessible.

title: [Lobsters] modshim: Override and customize Python packages without touching their code
content: modshim: Override and customize Python packages without touching their code

uplifting_analysis.reasoning: The modshim tool empowers developers to customize and improve existing Python packages without directly altering the original code. This fosters collaborative improvement and adaptation of software, benefiting a wide range of users by providing more flexible and tailored solutions. It also allows for easier adaptation to changing needs and bug fixes without breaking dependencies.
